pullrequest.title: First version of Displays widget with sample DisplayPlugins

content.raw:
Ignition GUI is not being "released" anytime soon; it is my understanding that some downstream users are building a specific revision from source while trying to keep up with what's in the default branch, and our development team is building `default` / `gz11` from source.

In practice, this means we're not committed to a stable API/ABI, but we've been trying not to push untested or partially functional code to default. 

If there is functionality you plan on getting to on future PRs, I'd recommend breaking this PR into smaller chunks so we don't leave anything "broken" on default. For example, you could make a first PR just with the grid display plugin and add the RTF in a future PR. Or maybe completely remove the visibility toggling functionality and add it later... Sounds reasonable?
content.html:
Ignition GUI is not being "released" anytime soon; it is my understanding that some downstream users are building a specific revision from source while trying to keep up with what's in the default branch, and our development team is building default / gz11 from source.

In practice, this means we're not committed to a stable API/ABI, but we've been trying not to push untested or partially functional code to default.

If there is functionality you plan on getting to on future PRs, I'd recommend breaking this PR into smaller chunks so we don't leave anything "broken" on default. For example, you could make a first PR just with the grid display plugin and add the RTF in a future PR. Or maybe completely remove the visibility toggling functionality and add it later... Sounds reasonable?

pullrequest.title: First version of Displays widget with sample DisplayPlugins

content.raw:
I’m on-board with not pushing partially functional code to default.  
I’ll leave the incomplete features in this PR for the review process \(I think it’s useful to see two types of displays\), and give another go at setting the visibility. If at the end it’s not resolved, I would be alright will dropping the RTF displaay plugin since it doesn’t use an overlay where it should and it might be a while before that task reaches the top of the stack.

If other blockers-for-merge come up, we can target this PR and followups at a feature branch, so the PRs can be reviewed in small pieces still, and then once the right level of functionality is in the feature branch we can merge that to default.
content.html:
I’m on-board with not pushing partially functional code to default.
I’ll leave the incomplete features in this PR for the review process (I think it’s useful to see two types of displays), and give another go at setting the visibility. If at the end it’s not resolved, I would be alright will dropping the RTF displaay plugin since it doesn’t use an overlay where it should and it might be a while before that task reaches the top of the stack.

If other blockers-for-merge come up, we can target this PR and followups at a feature branch, so the PRs can be reviewed in small pieces still, and then once the right level of functionality is in the feature branch we can merge that to default.

content.raw: I noticed that the derived classes are not overriding this function, and instead are overriding `Initialize`, which seems to serve the same purpose. You could mark this as final here to make sure no subclasses can implement `LoadConfig`.
content.html: I noticed that the derived classes are not overriding this function, and instead are overriding Initialize, which seems to serve the same purpose. You could mark this as final here to make sure no subclasses can implement LoadConfig.

pullrequest.title: First version of Displays widget with sample DisplayPlugins

content.raw: Final sounds like a good idea; not sure about `LoadDisplayConfig` because some plugins don’t do much with the config \(e.g. [the RTF one](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/137/first-version-of-displays-widget-with/diff#Lsrc/plugins/displays/RealtimeFactorDisplay.ccT86)\): `Initialize` is more to give them the chance to setup whatever visuals they need. If initialisation is also implied with the Load\* functions in the ignition framework, then that name could make sense!
content.html: Final sounds like a good idea; not sure about LoadDisplayConfig because some plugins don’t do much with the config (e.g. the RTF one): Initialize is more to give them the chance to setup whatever visuals they need. If initialisation is also implied with the Load* functions in the ignition framework, then that name could make sense!

pullrequest.title: First version of Displays widget with sample DisplayPlugins

content.raw: Humm I see. I try to only put on `LoadConfig` things which depend on the plugin configuration. Since `Initialize` takes the config pointer, I thought it served the same purpose. Do you foresee some initialization steps which don't depend on the config and cannot go on the constructor?
content.html: Humm I see. I try to only put on LoadConfig things which depend on the plugin configuration. Since Initialize takes the config pointer, I thought it served the same purpose. Do you foresee some initialization steps which don't depend on the config and cannot go on the constructor?

pullrequest.title: First version of Displays widget with sample DisplayPlugins

content.raw:
The flow is that the `DisplayPlugin`'s `LoadConfig` parses general display properties \(e.g. scene and engine\), and sets up the Visual for the subclass to use \(to attach whatever visuals it needs\). At the end of the parent `LoadConfig`, it \[calls the subclass' `Initialize](`[#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/137/first-version-of-displays-widget-with/diff#Lsrc/DisplayPlugin.ccT125](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/137/first-version-of-displays-widget-with/diff#Lsrc/DisplayPlugin.ccT125)\), to allow the subclass to setup its Visual. This initialization can't be done in the constructor of e.g. `GridDisplayPlugin` because at that time the scene/visual hasn’t been setup yet.

‌

We can separate the subclasses' `Initialize` and `LoadDisplayConfig`and call them separately.
content.html:
The flow is that the DisplayPlugin's LoadConfig parses general display properties (e.g. scene and engine), and sets up the Visual for the subclass to use (to attach whatever visuals it needs). At the end of the parent LoadConfig, it [calls the subclass' Initialize](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/137/first-version-of-displays-widget-with/diff#Lsrc/DisplayPlugin.ccT125), to allow the subclass to setup its Visual. This initialization can't be done in the constructor of e.g. GridDisplayPlugin because at that time the scene/visual hasn’t been setup yet.

‌

We can separate the subclasses' Initialize and LoadDisplayConfigand call them separately.

pullrequest.title: First version of Displays widget with sample DisplayPlugins

content.raw: Oh got it, so it needs to be done after the base class' `LoadConfig`, but doesn't necessarily need a config. I'm ok with leaving it the way it is, thanks for the clarification.
content.html: Oh got it, so it needs to be done after the base class' LoadConfig, but doesn't necessarily need a config. I'm ok with leaving it the way it is, thanks for the clarification.

pullrequest.title: First version of Displays widget with sample DisplayPlugins

content.raw:
On `Grid3D` we keep the grid name because since each plugin manages several grids, this is the way to tell which one of them the UI callback refers to.

Here, since each plugin is tied to a single grid, there's no need for that, so all the `gridName` lines could be removed.
content.html:
On Grid3D we keep the grid name because since each plugin manages several grids, this is the way to tell which one of them the UI callback refers to.

Here, since each plugin is tied to a single grid, there's no need for that, so all the gridName lines could be removed.

pullrequest.title: First version of Displays widget with sample DisplayPlugins

content.raw:
By an overlay you mean 2D text over the 3D scene? I think you can accomplish this just with Qt (no ign-rendering), by placing a widget on top of the Scene3D plugin. The caveat is that I'm almost certain it doesn't support transparency, so it will have a rectangular background, like Gazebo's GUI plugins. Is this what you mean?

![timer_gui.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/64K5zaR/images/990950791-timer_gui.png)
content.html: By an overlay you mean 2D text over the 3D scene? I think you can accomplish this just with Qt (no ign-rendering), by placing a widget on top of the Scene3D plugin. The caveat is that I'm almost certain it doesn't support transparency, so it will have a rectangular background, like Gazebo's GUI plugins. Is this what you mean?

pullrequest.title: First version of Displays widget with sample DisplayPlugins

content.raw: (or when you move to gz11, transparency is supported, see pull request #139 for example)
content.html: (or when you move to gz11, transparency is supported, see pull request #139 for example)

content.raw: Another idea if you want to have transparency right now would be to keep using 3D text, but attach it to (every? the first?) camera instead of the world, so it moves with the camera. The thing is that, if there are many cameras and you want one text per camera, one camera will see the other camera's text floating in the horizon :smile:
content.html: Another idea if you want to have transparency right now would be to keep using 3D text, but attach it to (every? the first?) camera instead of the world, so it moves with the camera. The thing is that, if there are many cameras and you want one text per camera, one camera will see the other camera's text floating in the horizon

pullrequest.title: First version of Displays widget with sample DisplayPlugins

content.html:
Some styling changes for your consideration:

diff -r f166f79d5e52 src/DisplayPlugin.cc
--- a/src/DisplayPlugin.cc      Mon Jul 09 18:34:07 2018 -0700
+++ b/src/DisplayPlugin.cc      Thu Jul 19 18:07:20 2018 -0700
@@ -141,7 +141,8 @@
 QWidget *DisplayPlugin::CreateProperties() const
 {
   auto propertiesLayout = new QHBoxLayout();
-  auto propertiesWidget = new QWidget();
+  propertiesLayout->setContentsMargins(0, 0, 0, 0);
+  propertiesLayout->setSpacing(0);

   // Create generic configuration options for all display plugins.
   auto visibleCheck = new QCheckBox(QString::fromStdString(this->title));
@@ -150,7 +151,13 @@
   visibleCheck->setChecked(this->dataPtr->visible);
   this->connect(visibleCheck,
     SIGNAL(toggled(bool)), this, SLOT(OnVisibilityChange(bool)));
-  propertiesLayout->addWidget(visibleCheck);
+
+  auto checkLayout = new QVBoxLayout();
+  checkLayout->addWidget(visibleCheck);
+  checkLayout->setContentsMargins(5, 10, 5, 0);
+
+  propertiesLayout->addLayout(checkLayout);
+  propertiesLayout->setAlignment(checkLayout, Qt::AlignTop);

   // Create the custom configuration options for this specific display plugin.
   auto customProperties = this->CreateCustomProperties();
@@ -168,6 +175,8 @@
     collapsible->AppendContent(customProperties);
     propertiesLayout->addWidget(collapsible);
   }
+
+  auto propertiesWidget = new QWidget();
   propertiesWidget->setLayout(propertiesLayout);

   return propertiesWidget;
diff -r f166f79d5e52 src/plugins/Displays.cc
--- a/src/plugins/Displays.cc   Mon Jul 09 18:34:07 2018 -0700
+++ b/src/plugins/Displays.cc   Thu Jul 19 18:07:20 2018 -0700
@@ -125,9 +125,12 @@
   scrollArea->setSizePolicy(QSizePolicy::Expanding, QSizePolicy::Expanding);

   auto layout = new QVBoxLayout();
+  layout->setContentsMargins(0, 0, 0, 0);
+  layout->setSpacing(0);
   layout->addWidget(scrollArea);

   this->setLayout(layout);
+  this->setMinimumWidth(550);
 }

 // Register this plugin

pullrequest.title: First version of Displays widget with sample DisplayPlugins

content.raw:
oh good, thank you for that! The AlignTop checkbox looks much better, and I like the compactness. I’ll incorporate that.

The minimum width I’m not sure on.. if no one ever intends to expand the grid properties I thought it would be good for them to be able to have a smaller Displays widget if they like.. I was thinking to reorganise the Grid’s properties so they take up less width. I think that the behaviour used to be that when the grid’s collapsible widget was expanded it would expand the Displays widget accordingly if it was too small, but a change that I made undid that behaviour. If you happen to know off the top of your head what property on what widget would bring that back we could include that instead? Otherwise, another day :slight_smile:

content.raw: Humm I can't think of anything right now. It looks like changing the size policy to `scrollArea->setSizePolicy(QSizePolicy::Minimum, QSizePolicy::Expanding);` at least ensures that the collapsed texts are always displayed. I imagine one possible hacky way to do it would be to capture resize events from the scroll area contents and adjust its minimum width accordingly. We can revisit this later ;)
content.html: Humm I can't think of anything right now. It looks like changing the size policy to scrollArea->setSizePolicy(QSizePolicy::Minimum, QSizePolicy::Expanding); at least ensures that the collapsed texts are always displayed. I imagine one possible hacky way to do it would be to capture resize events from the scroll area contents and adjust its minimum width accordingly. We can revisit this later ;)

pullrequest.title: First version of Displays widget with sample DisplayPlugins

content.raw: ah, I think I remember now that it use to greedily expand itself when expanded, but since we added the scroll area, it prefers to add the scrollbars instead. I think that was the part that changed the behaviour. Mostly just documenting this for my memory; haven’t tried your suggestion to address it yet.
content.html: ah, I think I remember now that it use to greedily expand itself when expanded, but since we added the scroll area, it prefers to add the scrollbars instead. I think that was the part that changed the behaviour. Mostly just documenting this for my memory; haven’t tried your suggestion to address it yet.

pullrequest.title: First version of Displays widget with sample DisplayPlugins

content.raw:
Works for me, thanks for addressing all the comments!

I really like the grid display, I think it's more useful than `Grid3D`. If the displays widget ever supports adding and removing displays, I think we can even get rid of `Grid3D`.

It doesn't make much sense to me to have the real time factor displayed in the 3D world like that though, but I imagine you must have your reasons. It would be really cool to make that configurable some day, so users can display 3D text from any arbitrary message. :angel: I would even argue that the plugin is so specific right now, that there's really not much use in it being shipped with ign-gui, perhaps you could consider either making it more general, or moving it to a downstream project.

Approving!
content.html:
Works for me, thanks for addressing all the comments!

I really like the grid display, I think it's more useful than Grid3D. If the displays widget ever supports adding and removing displays, I think we can even get rid of Grid3D.

It doesn't make much sense to me to have the real time factor displayed in the 3D world like that though, but I imagine you must have your reasons. It would be really cool to make that configurable some day, so users can display 3D text from any arbitrary message. I would even argue that the plugin is so specific right now, that there's really not much use in it being shipped with ign-gui, perhaps you could consider either making it more general, or moving it to a downstream project.

Approving!

content.raw:
Yeah I didn’t put too much time into refactoring the common grid code out between the two plugins because I imagined the same fate for Grid3D one day :slight_smile: 

I am open to shifting the RTF display out of this repo at some point \(it will also be good for testing the typical “user” experience of registering downstream plugins\)

‌

Appreciate the review; more PRs on their way!
